title-group.article-title: Prevalence of standing plantar pressure distribution variation in north Asian Indian patients with diabetes mellitus: A study to understand ulcer formation

article-meta.aff: 1Center for Biomedical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India
2Endocrinology and Metabolism Department, All India Institute of Medical Science, New Delhi, India

abstract.p: Diabetes Mellitus is a disorder of metabolism. Foot problems are common in diabetes and altered plantar pressures distribution may lead to ulceration in people with Diabetes Mellitus. Therefore the aim of this study was to investigate standing plantar pressure distribution variations in north Asian Indian diabetes mellitus subjects and its association with duration of diabetes. Thirty three subjects with age range from 40 to 75 years are recruited from AIIMS Endocrinology & metabolism lab Delhi, India and divided into three groups: 11 control subjects (non-diabetic), 11 diabetic subjects without neuropathy (DNN) and 11 diabetic subjects with neuropathy (DN). Neuropathy status was assessed by measuring loss of protective sensation to 10gm Semen’s Weinstein monofilament. Plantar pressure distributions parameter-Power ratio (PR) was measured during barefoot standing using portable PedoPowerGraph and results are analyzed using one way analysis of variance to detect significant difference between the groups. We found significant (p<0.05; p<0.01) difference in PR value between DN and CG groups in fore foot and hind foot but no significant (p>0.05) difference in PR value was found between DNN and CG groups in the foot. As compared to DNN, DN group have maximum PR variations in the fore foot. Plantar pressure distribution parameter-PR was higher with longer duration of diabetes among type 2 diabetes subjects. In this study we conclude that plantar pressure distribution parameter-PR was able to distinguish the DN groups from the CG group in hind and fore foot during standing. Increased forefoot PR value is prevalent in the diabetic neuropathic subjects and may be responsible for the occurrence of foot sole ulcers but additional prospective studies are needed. In the future we will investigate the plantar pressure distribution parameter-PR variations in diabetes with obese and osteoarthritis subject.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Diabetes mellitus (DM) is one of the most common metabolic disorders present all over the world.1 The most common form of diabetes is type 2 diabetes. This form of diabetes usually develops in adults aged 40 years and older and is most common in adults over the age of 55 years. Diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN) is a long-term complication of diabetes where exposure to high blood glucose levels over an extended period of time causes damage to the peripheral nerves in the arms, hands, legs, and feet.2 It is believed that approximately 50% of patients with diabetes will develop DPN within 10–15 years.3 The sequence of DPN is a progressive degeneration of the peripheral nerves, especially in the lower limbs, that can cause sensory and motor deficits that affect the biomechanics of the diabetic foot, as seen in ankle kinematics,3–5 gait kinetics,6,7 and plantar pressure distribution.8–11 Fifteen percent of the people with DM develop a foot ulcer,12 and 85% of major lower limb amputations are preceded by chronic ulceration. In general, diabetic foot ulcers result from repetitive high pressure applied to the plantar aspect of the foot while walking. Several researchers13–16 have reported that maximum peak pressures were developed under the metatarsal foot region consecutively build up a callus during barefoot walking. In addition, it has been suggested that high pressure may lead to tissue breakdown, resulting in ulcer formation. But there is some limitation that the plantar pressure measurement during walking does not depend up on the foot structure. Therefore, it is essential to find and quantify the pressure distribution over foot sole to help the clinician to make appropriate steps to prevent foot sole ulceration at an early stage.

Numerous studies8,17–19 have employed different plantar pressure measurement devices to demonstrate significant changes in pressure patterns while walking in people with diabetic neuropathy (DN) as compared to healthy patients. Also, increased plantar pressure due to alteration of musculoskeletal and plantar soft tissue loading is common among patients with DM, which may lead to ulceration.20 In fact, there is no absolute threshold pressure, as ulcers develop even below the accepted level of peak plantar pressures.3 Quantitative plantar pressures in some studies have produced contradictory results in terms of a normal pressure position, pattern, and value.21 However, most human beings spend large proportion of their walking hours in the standing position;21 yet surprisingly, little information is available about the plantar pressure distribution measurement and plantar soft tissue loading under metatarsal head in diabetic neuropathic foot during standing.13,22–24

Although there are studies25–29 on peak plantar pressure and plantar pressure distribution in diabetic patients using different pressure measuring systems (discrete transducers and sensors), these cannot quantify actual pressure change. Also, these systems (optical pedobarograph, Harris footprints, F-scan system, and flexi force sensor) are too expensive for screening patients in routine clinical examination3 and have 33% margin of error with low spatial resolution.30 In the past, some authors31–33 used optical pedobarograph to study diabetic feet while walking with different levels of loss of sensation and to quantify different parameters like foot pressure distributions parameter-power ratio (PR), foot sole hardness, and foot sole soft thickness, which may contribute to ulcer formation. But other investigators34,35 found that pressure gradient and shear stress on neuropathic forefoot can provide information about skin breakdown, which seem to be contradictory.

More recently, Sawacha et al.36 assess neuropathic biomechanic impairment by comparing normal and pathological kinematic analyses. However, this kinematic analysis cannot be easily applied in patients with peripheral neuropathies because of rigid mounting plates by means of elastic bandages and lengthy anatomical calibration procedures.37–40 Researchers have used different pressure measuring systems and investigated peak values, pressure/time integrals, bidimensional maps of maximum or mean pressures, and peak shear stress under the foot sole. However, analyzing these parameters requires complex processing tools and often leads to qualitative observations only. Static studies are quite useful in many clinical applications where it is suspected that one foot is weaker than the other. For the above-mentioned reasons, the study described in the present article mainly based on the analysis of static foot pressure image to obtain plantar pressure distribution parameter-PR in north Asian Indian type 2 diabetic patients during standing and its association with duration of diabetes. Therefore, the aim of this study was to investigate standing foot pressure distribution variation in type 2 diabetic patients using portable PedoPowerGraph® (PPG) and to compare the PR value between the three groups in the specified foot sole region and its association with duration of diabetes. We hypothesized that type 2 diabetes that show an altered foot pressure distribution pattern during standing would provide additional information about risk status of foot in neuropathic patients at early stage as compared to patients who had not yet developed neuropathy. In addition, we hypothesized that standing plantar pressure distribution increases with the increase in duration of diabetes.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The patients were recruited from clinics of AIIMS, Biomedical and Endocrinological Laboratory New Delhi, India. All the patients were informed about the procedures fully and have given informed consent before data recording.

sec.title: Patients’ details
sec.p: Foot pressure intensity image is acquired for 33 patients with both feet standing on portable PPG pressure measurement platform and is analyzed using image processing technique in frequency domain. In this study, we divided the patients into three groups: 11 patients with healthy feet (control group (CG)), 11 patients with DN (DN group), and 11 patients without DN (DNN group) with age ranging from 40 to 75 years. The healthy patient groups were volunteers and relatives of the patients. The healthy volunteers acted as matched controls to reflect weight (kg), height (m), body mass index (BMI; kg/m2), and age (years) of the diabetic patients. The inclusion criteria for the diabetic groups (DNN and DN) were type II diabetes. Duration of diabetes for diabetic groups (DNN and DN) ranged from 2 to 15 years and from 5 to 20 years, respectively. Also, inclusion criteria for the groups with DN were unable to sense the 10-gm Semmes Weinstein monofilament (SWMF) on at least two sites on the plantar foot as described elsewhere.41 Patients were excluded if they had major foot shape alterations by visual inspection, one leg amputees, patients with instability who are unable to undergo the foot pressure measurements, use of any assistive devices for walking (walking sticks/canes), had foot ulcers at the time of evaluation, and had discharging wounds.

sec.title: Experimental procedures
sec.p: First sociodemographic profile data were collected, and the patients were asked whether or not they were diabetic and the type and duration of diabetes. As part of the screening procedures, a foot inspection was conducted by a podiatrist in order to identify foot deformities, and foot types (i.e. hammer toes and cavus/planus) were not included as criteria for this study. At screening stage, the presence of neuropathy was confirmed by testing the loss of protective sensation (LOPS) using the 10-gm SWMF,42 which exerts 10 gm force when pressed perpendicular against the skin of the sole of the foot areas as mentioned in Figure 1(a). The loss of sensation in more than two areas of the foot is suggestive of insensate foot.41

sec.title: Standing plantar foot pressure image acquisition instrumentation setup
sec.p: After initial screening stage, foot pressure intensity image was acquired using portable PPG, a device based on continuous image transduction principle.43 This device measures plantar pressure distribution characterized by a parameter called PR for pathological feet in foot clinics.33 During static plantar pressure measurements, all patients will be barefooted and both the feet were placed on a deformable plastic sheet (2 mm thick, 60 cm long, and 50 cm width having a surface structure of 0.03–0.02 mm), which was placed over the glass plate (dimension of length: 57 cm; breadth: 44 cm; thickness: 12 mm) platform in the system. They were asked to look at a constant point on the wall, which was 3 m away to reduce the error due to wrong tended posture causing overpressure on one side of the foot. An image of the foot sole of the patients and a reference image (without patient standing on the machine) were captured using a Canon digital camera with wide-angle lens, focal length, f = 2.5 cm, and the image was imported to the personal computer (PC) using WinDVR software. The patients were asked to stand on the PPG system for about 5 s with both the feet separated based on their normal style of standing. Figure 2 shows PPG instrumentation setup during barefoot standing of the normal patient. The standing foot pressure images are obtained from the portable PPG system, and plantar pressure distribution parameter-PR was calculated by specially developed software as explained in the following.

sec.title: Calculation of plantar pressure distribution parameter-PR
sec.p: The foot image was acquired using acquisition software (WinDVR) in bitmap (BMP) file format. The BMP images of the foot have varying intensities of light distributions over the length and breadth of the foot image. However, the size of each individual footprint varies, but each foot pressure image is divided into 10 standard regions, indicated in Figure 1(a) as per the method.44,45 Then, the BMP images of the foot are analyzed in the frequency domain analysis using image processing to obtain PR as shown in the following.

sec.title: Frequency domain analysis of foot image
sec.p: For our frequency domain analysis, we have focused on the pressure distribution in all regions of the foot. Each of these image distributions in the foot sole areas contains high and low frequency variations of light intensities. sec.title: Statistical comparison analysis
sec.p: For our analysis, the foot sole areas are divided into three areas, as shown in Figure 1(b). The three areas were H1—hindfoot (areas 1 and 2); M1—midfoot (areas 3 and 4); and F1—forefoot (areas 5–7). The mean PR value was calculated for three foot areas, as shown in Figure 1(b). Also, the PR value of the big toe (area 8) was not considered for our result analysis because there was improper placement of big toe (foot area 8) in PPG system and was highly subjective toward standing posture among patients. One-way analysis of variance with post hoc t-tests with the Bonferroni correction was used to test the patient demographic profile data (age, weight, height, and BMI) differences between the three groups (CG, DNN, and DN). Data from both right and left feet are analyzed. Foot pressure distribution parameter-PR data are analyzed using one-way analysis of variance followed by post hoc t-test (MATLAB software) to find significant difference among groups (between paired groups of patients: DN vs CG, DN vs DNN, and DNN vs CG). In addition, we performed the analysis on relationship between PR values in foot areas with different ranges of duration of diabetic groups (i.e. 1–5, 6–10, and >15 years) using one-way analysis of variance followed by post hoc t-test to find any significant difference in PR values among groups (Group 3 vs Group 1, Group 3 vs Group 2, and Group 2 vs Group 1). The p-values of <0.01, <0.05, and <0.001 were considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In the present study, we have investigated and analyzed 33 patients with bipedal standing. Table 1 reveals that there is no statistically significant (p > 0.05) difference detected among age, BMI, height, weight, and duration of diabetes between the groups. For our result analysis, the foot sole areas such as hindfoot (areas 1 and 2), midfoot (areas 3 and 4), and forefoot (areas 5–7), as shown in Figure 1(b), are analyzed and obtained the results of variation of PR in both feet of patients with healthy feet (CG), DNN, and DN separately in frequency domain by performing FFT, as shown in Table 2. Figure 3(a) to (c) shows pseudo color representation of plantar pressure distribution in both feet for different patient groups separately. Comparisons of PR value between groups are shown in Table 2. DN group presented statistically higher PR values than CG (p< 0.05) and DNN group (p<0.05) at forefoot (F1) and hindfoot (H1) because the intensity image of DN feet has higher power distribution over forefoot and hindfoot in frequency domain. However, no significant difference was detected when comparison was carried out between DNN group and CG in terms of right foot and left foot PR values, as shown in Table 2. Mean forefoot PR value is higher in the DN group as compared to CG, as shown in Table 2. We have found that maximum PR value was higher in DN group under the forefoot as compared to CG and DNN group, as shown in Table 2. We have found that there is a significant higher PR value in the forefoot that may be responsible for the occurrence of foot sole ulcers in DN as compared with CG and DNN patients as mentioned in Table 2. The relationship between different ranges of durations of diabetes and PR values in type 2 diabetic patient for both feet are shown in Table 3. We have found significant higher PR values (p<0.001; p<0.05; p<0.01) in the hindfoot and forefoot, but we did not find significant higher PR value (p>0.05) in midfoot for longer duration of diabetic group (i.e. Group 3) than Group 1, as shown in Table 3. In addition, we did not find significant higher PR values (p > 0.05) in hindfoot, midfoot, and forefoot for Group 2 as compared to Groups 1 and 3, as shown in Table 3.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we evaluate the standing plantar pressure distribution parameter-PR in north Asian Indian type 2 diabetic patients using portable PPG as compared to CG. The results of our study demonstrate a significant difference (p<0.05; p<0.01) in PR value on the hindfoot and forefoot of people with DN when compared to healthy group of people without DN. Altered PR value in patients with DN is due to very HFP in frequency domain as compared to control patients. Hence, HFP is attributed to more foot pressure distribution variation and could be seen from the difference in the color intensities as mentioned in Figure 3(a) to (c). Unlike previous studies,28,31,33 we did not find any difference between groups for PR value in the midfoot because there is an increase in TP and a decrease in HFP resulting in low foot pressure distribution variation.

Prabhu et al.31 and Rahman et al.28 have evaluated PR with different levels of loss of sensation for early detection of plantar ulcers while walking. Also, PR was able to distinguish normal feet from diabetic feet with different levels of loss of sensation while walking.31 From the present study, we have also found that the pressure distribution parameter-PR was able to distinguish the DN patients from the CG patients during standing. PR is more for the DN patients, and it falls significantly as compared to the CG patients in the forefoot and hindfoot. Foot ulcer could occur at higher level of sensation loss (i.e. LOPS to 10-gm monofilament) with high PR values (i.e. 35–45)31 in different foot sole areas of patient with DN. Hence, these findings provide support to the importance of considering standing plantar pressure distribution between groups who are at risk for foot ulceration.

From the literature,3 it has long been known that DN is a chronic consequence of DM, and the risk of ulceration increases with the degree of sensational loss. In addition, other factors such as sensorial, autonomic, and motor dysfunctions may be related to the pathogenesis of ulceration. Also, some of the previous studies have shown that plantar pressure distribution patterns varied in accordance with the initiation of foot insensitivity.47,48 However, an earlier stage of neuropathy can cause foot ulcer than those with the history of foot ulcers.49 But one study32 has shown that the plantar pressure values found for DN group were not considered being a risk for foot ulceration at early stage. However, patients with DN can develop ulceration even under normal plantar pressure values with the progression of neuropathy3 and increased foot sole hardness variation in those areas. Though other researchers31–33,43 have reported that the parameter-PR is an accurate parameter to evaluate the concept of foot pressure distribution during walking than peak plantar pressure, which for the previous 3 years has been the only biomechanical parameters associated with ulcer formation, the present study suggests altered pressure distribution in the neuropathic patients resulting in abnormal pattern in the hindfoot and forefoot, as observed in the literature.43 Furthermore, the presence of elevated plantar pressure distribution shown by the parameter-PR can also be associated with other biomechanical factors, such as foot sole hardness and thickness,32,33 which were not the emphasis of the present study. We have shown that the parameter-PR associated with the duration of diabetes among type 2 diabetic patients is in contradict to the Viswanathan et al.’s50 study. Patient with longer duration of diabetes is likely to have higher level of sensation loss (LOPS to 10-gm monofilament), which further alter the PR value in the hindfoot and forefoot.

Considering these facts, neuropathy itself first alters foot pressure distribution parameter-PR, then the ulcers occur, and after healing, reulceration occurs because the foot pressure distribution pattern remains altered and worsens the plantar pressure distribution.43 One potential advantage of the current investigation was foot pressure distribution measurement system (i.e. PPG) that measures foot pressure distribution characterized by parameter-PR in a clinical setting and gives results in pseudo color-coded format that can be made available immediately to both the patient and doctor.

sec.title: Limitation
sec.p: The number of patients in our study was relatively small. Another limitation of this study was lack of prospective study data. Further limitation of this study was we did not have data on loss of sensation as tested using different monofilament levels.

sec.title: Conclusions and future study
sec.p: Plantar pressure distribution measurements are useful in the analysis and understanding of the biomechanics of human foot in bipedal standing. Earlier researchers have suggested different parameters for finding risk status of the foot in DM patient. This study shows that plantar pressure distribution parameter-PR is higher in the forefoot and hindfoot of DN groups due to diabetic sensation loss (i.e. LOPS to 10-gm monofilament). Also, the present investigation shows that the mean PR values are able to distinguish the normal feet from diabetic feet with LOPS during standing. More specifically, our result shows that there is significant variation in forefoot PR value in both feet of patients with DN group as compared to other groups. Thus, this result could help in finding risk status of foot at early stage by analyzing the parameter-PR variation in diabetic neuropathic patients during standing, but additional prospective studies are needed. Further research studies are needed to investigate other contributing factors such as foot and ankle joint mobility, musculoskeletal, foot deformities, and vascular deficits for foot ulceration in neuropathic groups. In addition, the above-mentioned study will also provide useful information regarding plantar pressure distribution over the foot sole during standing and thus establish the factors that are useful for biomedical engineers to design orthotic devices and doctors to conduct corrective foot surgery in patient with DN feet to offload excessive high pressure for prevention of foot ulceration. Therefore, optical based noninvasive plantar pressure distribution instrumentation could be used as a standard clinical tool for diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.
